content:
Can you please explain the time limits better in the constraints of the puzzle.
I deduce 1000 ms at the start and 50 ms per turn  ?

If this is wrong please add it.

Can you please add an option to remove autoplay?
It's sometimes impossible to use fc-solver tips because of autoplay.
I don't see "T for 10 (Ten)" in the rules...

I would like to ask ffgth, Konstant and VivienBillot - have you solved this puzzle? Did you spot any issues with it, or inconsistencies compared to any other puzzle on the platform? I genuinely love this contribution, but there were still few small things that needed tweaking and now this is approved with useless comments like "good", "well done"? Are we just hunting contribution quest, really?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: good !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Well done
Freecell & minesweeper... my personal tools for procrastination! LOL

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: fun
Nice work. Good Luck <3

Thanks for this. 
I am still looking at this project, but it made me discover the coding game SDK also :)

One more question as I've fixed my bugs with home moves. The testcase called "Impossible Game" can't be solved, is this correct? I've tried using fc-solve and it runs out of iterations, same for my algorithm. Wondering how to have it "green", or we're not supposed to solve it? I've never encountered a testcase which is supposed to fail (unless I've missed it in description and we somehow can output "unsolvable" or something like that).

Let me start off by saying that this is incredibly well done.
I had some issues with the input initially - but it has been resolved.
It's not the most friendly puzzle to debug, but there's lots of information, so that's to be expected. I fought much more with autoplay than anything else to be honest. I finally have solution which is able to solve some games, but it seems I still have something wrong with home moves removal so I had to remove few home moves manually to see if my solution works - luckily it does.

Feedback for the puzzle:

1) In my opinion the most important one - ability to turn off autoplay, as currently there's much more issue than gain with it.

2) Detailed description about how the autoplay works - in order to solve the puzzle you have to remove those moves which will be auto-played, unless someone is trying to find a new solution each turn and providing only one turn per move (guess that's possible, but I've used python and haven't tried that approach)

3) Information about turn time limit and maximum allowed moves in total in description - it's really nice to have as it's a great and quick way to judge how advanced solution you probably have to write (for example with easy puzzles you often know that you can use bruteforce if the puzzle spec has small inputs)

4) Very minor - maybe add information in the output which move is being executed on a certain turn (and when a turn is auto-play)? Mostly an issue with readability while trying to watch the game slowly and outputing multiple moves in a single turn, easily fixed by player when he outputs a single move per turn.

More than happy to approve in few days, once I'll have a bit more time to remove my home moves issue in my code and maybe some optimizations are still required to solve harder games. Great job!

Works well.
Nice contribution.
Nice !
nice work
Very Good
J'adore ce jeu . C'est bien de le mettre en exercise :)
POG

I've updated the identifiers to ridiculously descriptive "foundationCountPlusOne". So now it compiles in all languages but Go (but who cares, it's the stub generator's choice), and runs in all remaining but Clojure (Timeout, I don't know why, please tell me), F# (IndexOutOfRangeException, I don't know why, please tell me) and Ocaml (Timeout, I don't know why, please tell me).
java code does not compile
Stub crashes in C#

The gameplay is complete. The graphics are complete. A few backward-compatible cosmetic and playing options are in the pipe, but as far as solving goes, it's ready and good to try out, and actually publishable as far as my standards go. So I'm taking it out of WIP.

Now maybe I could start working on a solver of my own.

My todo-lists:
☑ cleanup
☐ more cleanup
☑ graphics
  ☑ game number
  ☑ a tolerable icon
  ☑ end screen
☑ animation
  ☑ card counter
  ☐ supermove split
  ☐ bonus end screen
☑ game protocol
  ☐ autoplay selector
  ☑ move queueing
In some languages "fc+1" became "fc_1"... Stub magic. ^^

Full code http://chat.codingame.com/pastebin/b32283a8-6298-4dfd-b4b2-8db4a53c7417

On it, thanks!

We know. See other comments.
Replace "_1" with "+1" in the meantime.

For F# the problem is that you reuse an array (words) that is initially sized at 1 and is then supposed to contain 8 elements. Strangely enough F# won't throw an error here, but it won't do anything either. Hence the index out of range exception in the cascade loop.

Thanks a lot for trying it out and taking the time to provide feedback!

To address your points:
(1) has been in the plan since the start (along with netcell-style). It'll get there. Eventually.
(2) ditto.
(3) they're the platform defaults. I haven't actually thought about them, what settings do you think would make sense? IIRC the platform constraints are: <=30s aggregated per game, >=50ms per turn.
(4) great idea.  That might actually come up first as it's easiest to implement.

It's MS game #11982.

No one has ever found a solution for it using the MS ruleset. But to the best of my knowledge it hasn't ever been proven unsolvable, so you can still become famous by being the first.

You don't need to solve it to pass the validators.
I'd guess not, seeing as *nobody* has solved this puzzle yet.
Thank you for reporting. I'll try and find the time to look into it.

I don't have much time for that currently, but your contribution is welcome.

From memory, autoplay is there originally because it's mostly necessary to complete games in time with the limited number of frames the API allows.

Ok, it's a fun challenge to help in coding my first contribution,
I will look at it seriously in fews weeks, thanks for the invitation to add tiny modification.

(3) Information in description would be very useful when reading about the puzzle - 1 second during the first turn, then 50ms per turn, 200 turns available (I think that's the standard, but I could test it out more thoroughly).

I need to improve my algorithm a bit to see how hard it is to solve the game in that time, but it seems rather promising - the example game takes less than 100ms to solve in my current python solution.
I didn't understand any of that. Do you have a fix?

Yes, don't use the same array for reading line 3 (Foundation) and lines 5 to 12 (cascades). I tested it manually by declaring a new array and it works.

To reword my previous post : the array used to read line 3 ends up being size 1, for the 1st test at least. The cascade input has a length of 8 however, and if you reuse the previous array to receive that data, F# seems to ignore the read entirely (idk why). Then when looping cascade1CountPlusOne times the indexing goes over 1 and throws.

But that's the stub generator's doing! I don't have control over that, do I?

(PS: sorry for the delay, there's a bit of noise in the notifications…)
Not sure, my knowledge of the stub generator is limited. If you can't then it's clearly a problem for CG to fix, and your stub code should stay as is.
ok jbm

012746ef     Tighten tableau formation to when they actually touch/intersect.  Kudos @eulerscheZahl

Currently uploading.

Edit: uploaded.
Thanks, now I understand the expected output format too.

Thanks both.

I'm afraid I'm going to have to dismiss as "WONTFIX" for stub limitations. I will add a note though, thanks. :shrug:

Edit: mmmmk, not that easy. I'll write up on the options and poll in the forum.

First follow-up:

In my defence, it worked in all the languages I tried (Haskell, C++, Perl).
I just ran the numbers, it works for 16/27 (60%) of the platform.  For 8 languages (including C# as you noticed) it fails because for whatever reason the stub generator replaces + by _.

(for one of them (Clojure), the failure is a very reasonable way of saying "fc+1" is not an expression; for two of them (F# and Ocaml) I have no idea what's going on).

So it'd be 90% if there wasn't that substitution.

To be continued.
